summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case, focusing on the review and production of 'Highly Confidential' images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences and devices. The emails discuss discrepancies in image counts, logistical arrangements for evidence review, and the de-designation process for sensitive materials.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, specifically regarding the review of 'Highly Confidential' images and videos seized from Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office, copied on emails regarding discovery coordination in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney copied on emails discussing discovery deficiencies and protective order issues in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Defendant in the criminal case, referenced in discussions about her right to review discovery materials, including 'Highly Confidential' images, while in custody at MDC.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose New York and Virgin Islands residences were searched, leading to the seizure of CDs and electronic devices containing the 'Highly Confidential' images and videos at issue.

connections.description: Menninger is the defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, advocating for her access to discovery materials.
Implicit connection as Maxwell is on trial for crimes related to Epstein's activities; evidence seized from Epstein's properties is central to the case against her.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for U.S. v. Maxwell
events.description: Trial date mentioned in the correspondence as November 29, 2021, around which discovery preparation timelines are discussed.

events.title: Production of Confidential Images
events.description: Reference to a recent production of confidential images dated August 5, 2021, which included HTML files similar to those containing HC images.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York the week of April 13, 2021, to review evidence, including 'Highly Confidential' materials on hard drives at 500 Pearl Street.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (location for evidence review)
1 St. Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office address)
Denver, CO (FBI field office for evidence review)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held)
New York residence of Jeffrey Epstein (location of CD seizure)
Virgin Islands residence of Jeffrey Epstein (location of device seizure)
keyFacts: Prosecutors confirm a discrepancy in the number of 'Highly Confidential' (HC) images initially reported; the correct number matches an FBI 302 report and was available on hard drives for review.
HC images originated from two sources: CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence and electronic devices seized during his arrest and searches of his New York and Virgin Islands residences.

Defense attorney Laura Menninger raises significant concerns about the ability to review discovery, citing corrupt files, missing metadata, and lack of appropriate software to view thousands of images.
The government states that HC materials cannot be copied or removed from FBI property and must be reviewed on a government laptop in the presence of an FBI employee.

The Protective Order defines 'Highly Confidential' material as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals,' not limited to child pornography.
